H0.text: Farming has most likely had the greatest effect on erosion of the top layer of soil, reducing its average thickness from about 23 cm when European settlers first came to North America to less than 15 cm today.

H1.text: Restoring wetlands has most likely had the greatest effect on erosion of the top layer of soil, as the average thickness fell from about 23 cm when European settlers first came to North America to less than 15 cm today.

H2.text: Species reintroduction is the factor that has most likely had the greatest effect on erosion of the top layer of soil, reducing its average thickness from approximately 23 cm when European settlers first arrived to less than 15 cm today.

H3.text: Excessive groundwater use is the factor that most likely had the greatest effect on erosion of the top layer of soil, reducing its average thickness from approximately 23 cm when European settlers first came to North America to less than 15 cm today.

A4.text: Unsustainable agricultural practices increase rates of erosion by one to two orders of magnitude over the natural rate and far exceed replacement by soil production.

A5.text: The tillage of agricultural lands, which breaks up soil into finer particles, is one of the primary factors increasing erosion rates.
